column3: Obama administration pushes for more computer science education
column5: by Blair Hanley Frank, IDG News Service
column6: The United States may direct billions of dollars funding towards teaching America's youth computer science, if President Obama has his way.

column3: Periodic Table Droid Helps You Learn Chemistry
column6: If you want to learn more about Chemistry, this app provides a wealth of detail about the Periodic Table, atomic elements and their properties.

column3: 13 awesome science apps to express your inner nerd
A look at the world's most powerful X-ray laser
column5: by Melissa Aparicio, IDG News Service
column6: Research at SLAC's Linac Coherent Light Source is used to develop future data storage systems and electronics

column3: Computer Science Grads Fielding 'Multiple Job Offers'
column6: It's good to be a computer science major these days.

column3: Sony is building new battery chemistry to make smartphones last much longer
column6: Sony's lithium-sulfur and magnesium-sulfur batteries could improve smartphone battery life by 40 percent in five years.

column3: Science Mag Launches Fiction Spinoff
column5: by John P. Mello Jr, PCWorld
column6: MIT's Technology Review branches out into "hard" science fiction with a second edition, both in print and digital.

column3: Computer Science Enrollments Rebound, Up 10% Last Fall
column6: For the third year, computer science enrollments have increased.

column3: The art and science of risk management
column6: A new survey from Tripwire explores whether risk management is more science, or art.

column3: Khan Academy to Launch Computer Science Curriculum
column5: by Joab Jackson, IDG News Service
column6: On Wednesday, free online tutorial service Khan Academy will launch a new series of instructional videos covering the field of computer science.

column3: Getting started with molecular gastronomy
column7: Molecular gastronomy is the art of combining science lab methods with kitchen ingredients. Here's how to get started! (2:44)

column3: 10 Ideas from DARPA
column7: Thought-provoking questions on computer science and machine learning (5:37)

column3: Lighting Science wants its Good Night Bulb to put you to sleep
column7: The LED bulb removes blue hues of light that can keep you up at night, while another product -- the Alert & Awake Bulb-- helps you get started on your day. (0:59)

column3: Basis Peak is the perfect activity tracker for hardcore quantified-selfers
column7: With automatic event logging and breakthrough heart-rate monitoring, the Basis Peak is a wrist-worn window into your own body science. (2:09)

column3: Case study: Using VCloud to replicate data offsite
column6: At VMworld, Network World chatted with Tom White, IT Director at Environmental Science Corp., about how he virtualized disaster recovery using cloud technologies.

column3: Interested in cooking sous-vide style? The Anova Precision Cooker makes it easy.
column7: This French method of cooking by placing food inside a vacuum-sealed bag and boiling it at a controlled temperature is an art and a science. This device makes it easy for the home chef. (0:41)

column3: Interview: Whitney Bouck, COO, HelloSign
column7: IDG CMO Perspectives provides insight into the state of Marketing across industries from leading business executives. Whitney Bouck, HelloSign’s Chief Operating Officer, speaks to Josh London, CMO of IDG and shares her thoughts on using insights to drive a better customer experience, the art and science of marketing and the importance of finding your service evangelists. (8:31)

column3: Interview: Simon Mulcahy, Interim CMO, Salesforce
column7: IDG CMO Perspectives provides insight into the state of Marketing across industries from leading business executives. Simon Mulcahy, interim CMO of Salesforce, speaks to Josh London, CMO of IDG and shares his thoughts on using insights to suggest next steps for customer outreach at exactly the right time, balancing the art and science of marketing and the Dreamforce Experience. (6:57)

column3: Interview: Fred Studer, CMO, Gigamon
column7: IDG CMO Perspectives provides insight into the state of Marketing across industries from leading business executives. Fred Studer, CMO of Gigamon, speaks to Josh London, CMO of IDG, and shares his insights on creative messaging through the art and science of marketing, along with development and use of new marketing concepts, among other topics. (5:34)

column3: Gravity still works and these pumpkins prove it
column7: Physics students pushed 36 pumpkins off a Boston University roof in honor of an experiment conducted by Galileo in the 1600s. (1:22)

column3: Hands-on: Omnity's search tool
column7: Omnity is a research tool for enterprises that allows for searches based on phrases and context rather than relying on simple keywords. The results -- in both visual and textual formats -- can allow academics and corporate users to supercharge their searches and more easily glean information from disparate sources. Sponsored by the National Science Foundation, Omnity uses algorithms that find connections between the rarely shared words in a sentence or paragraph and then research those connections. (0:50)

column3: Interview: Karen Walker, CMO, Cisco
column7: IDG CMO Perspectives provides insight into the state of Marketing across industries from leading business executives. Karen Walker, CMO of Cisco, sat down for a three-part IDG CMO Perspectives series with Josh London, IDG’s CMO, to share her thoughts on marketing at Cisco. In Part 1, Karen and Josh discuss the art and science of marketing, the CMO’s evolving role and predictive marketing, among other things. (5:01)

column3: Tech gifts for every budget
column7: Looking for a great holiday gift for family, friends or colleagues? Check out this collection of tech gear to suit every taste and budget. (4:34)

column3: Human or humanoid? Tokyo museum hires new guides
column7: The robots meant to anticipate a time when androids are so lifelike that humans may have difficulty distinguishing them. Follow reporter Nick Barber on Twitter @nickjb (1:26)

column3: Hubo the robot meets the rich and influential
column7: At the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos, Switzerland, on Monday, the DARPA-winning Hubo robot impressed attendees with its moves. Its presence highlights a future question for the global economy. (2:00)

column3: Drone registration, autonomous cars, astronaut recruitment - The Wrap
column7: You'll have to register that new drone you get, California is opening its roads to public use of autonomous cars and NASA is looking for new astronauts. Follow host Nick Barber on Twitter @nickjb (3:02)

column3: MIT Media Lab celebrates 30 with Martha Stewart, magicians and visionaries
column7: MIT's Media Lab celebrated its 30th anniversary with tech visionaries including Marvin Minsky, Alan Kay and Danny Hillis. (2:54)

column3: Japanese androids hold news conference, chat with baby droids
column7: At the Miraikan museum in Tokyo, robots are one step closer to taking over. Two female androids held their own news conference, with little participation from human beings. (1:26)

column3: NASA will experiment with fire in space
column7: NASA will deliberately start a fire in space. Engineers are hoping to learn more about how fire spreads in zero gravity, and with that knowledge make safer space missions. (2:18)

column3: Hololens explores a jet engine
column7: As part of its push to get businesses using Hololens, Microsoft showed off a Japan Airlines app that lets engineers explore jet engines during training. (2:05)
